title: Amber Guyger case: judge defends hugging woman who killed man in his home
text:
Judge Tammy Kemp embraced Amber Guyger at the conclusion of a trial ‘to encourage Ms Guyger because she has a lot of life to live’

A judge has defended her actions after she hugged a white former Dallas police officer who had fatally shot her black neighbour, and also gave her a Bible.

Botham Jean's father: I forgive Amber Guyger but I wanted stiffer sentence Read more

Judge Tammy Kemp embraced Amber Guyger, 31, at the conclusion of a trial in which she was sentenced to 10 years in prison for killing Botham Jean, 26, after mistakenly entering his apartment in September 2018.

Jean was black. Guyger, who is white, reached out to hug Kemp after the judge handed her a bible to read while incarcerated.

Kemp, who is black, said her actions were appropriate because the trial had ended.

“I came down to extend my condolences to the Jean family and to encourage Ms Guyger because she has a lot of life to live,” the judge told the Associated Press.

“She asked me if I thought that God could forgive her and I said, ‘Yes, God can forgive you and has.’ If she wanted to start with the Bible, I didn’t want her to go back to the jail and to sink into doubt and self-pity and become bitter. Because she still has a lot of life ahead of her following her sentence and I would hope that she could live it purposefully.”

I don’t understand the anger. Judge Tammy Kemp

The embrace sparked fierce criticism. A secular group, the Freedom From Religion Foundation, filed a complaint with Texas authorities over what it argues is judicial misconduct.

The complaint alleges Kemp committed an “egregious abuse of power” by displaying her religious beliefs while carrying out her duties.

Kemp rejected that argument, telling AP: “I could not refuse that woman a hug.”

She added: “And I don’t understand the anger. And I guess I could say if you profess religious beliefs and you are going to follow them, I would hope that they not be situational and limited to one race only.”

The judge was not the only person to reach out to Guyger in court. Jean’s younger brother, Brandt, also hugged Guyger, telling her he forgave her.

“I’m speaking for myself, not my family, but I love you just like anyone else,” he said.

Jean’s father, Bertrum, has said he also forgives Guyger, though he thinks her sentence should have been longer. Prosecutors sought 28 years, the age Jean would have been now had he lived.

Guyger lived one floor below Jean and said she entered his apartment thinking it was hers. She shot him because she said she thought he was a burglar. Jean was sitting watching TV and eating ice cream at the time of the incident.

Criminal justice groups expressed relief at the relatively rare sight of a white police officer being convicted for killing an unarmed black man. But some have criticized the outpouring of forgiveness towards Guyger.

The trauma of the case has been further exacerbated by the killing of a witness who gave evidence during the trial.

Joshua Brown, who lived in the same apartment complex as Jean and Guyger and testified he heard two people talking followed by gunfire, was himself shot dead in Dallas on Friday. Police have yet to publicly identify a motive or suspect for the crime.
